title.english: The Night is Short, Walk on Girl

description:
A black haired girl is walking around the streets of Kyoto, from the night scene of Pontocho to a second-hand book fair in Shimogamo, then off to a college fair. The main character that has a romantic feeling for her secretly follows her around and looks for the opportunities to run into her in a manner that seems like a coincidence. Unfortunately for him, she is not interested in love yet, so she does not notice his feelings. What awaits these two characters are a series of crazy incidents caused by bizarre individuals, such as a person who introduces himself as Tengu, the god of second-hand books, or a money lender, who collects young men's underwear and lives on a three story barge.

(Source: Sugoi Japan, edited)

Best known for his individual designs outside of the industry's norm.

Originating from Studio Dove. Itou started as an in-betweener on [Zettai Muteki Raijin Ou](https://anilist.co/anime/1897/) and made his debut as a character designer on the series [Kemonozume](https://anilist.co/anime/1454/), directed by [Masaaki Yuasa](https://anilist.co/staff/100068/). He has since designed the characters for most of Yuasa's works.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/Tomihiko_Morimi) | [Blog](https://tomio.hatenablog.com/)
 
A Japanese writer from Nara Prefecture. He graduated from Kyoto University and his works often have Kyoto as the setting.

name.native: アジアン・カンフー・ジェネレーション

node.description:
[Website](http://www.asiankung-fu.com) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/AKG_information) | [Youtube](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC52_sWDVAOwq5TaaA44kp-A)

Asian Kung-Fu Generation, stylized as ASIAN KUNG-FU GENERATION, is a Japanese alternative rock band formed in 1996.

Starting out as a college band, they released a series of independent EPs featuring lyrics mostly sung in English. In 2002, they released their major-label EP debut Hokai Amplifier, from that point singing their lyrics in Japanese. The band's musical style is influenced by seminal Western alternative rock acts as well as their own local Japanese indie-rock and punk scene. Their songs incorporate various aspects of the genres, most typically expressing fast tempos and prominent power chord guitar riffs in addition to rhythmic groove and emotional lyrics. Despite the indie nature of their music, the band has enjoyed worldwide commercial success in addition to critical acclaim.

They have also been cited as one of the best, most balanced modern rock bands to emerge from Japan in the '00s.

__Members:__
- [Masafumi Gotou](https://anilist.co/staff/159934/) - vocalist
- [Kensuke Kita](https://anilist.co/staff/220702/) - guitarist
- [Takahiro Yamada](https://anilist.co/staff/159937/) - bassist
- [Kiyoshi Ijichi](https://anilist.co/staff/220703/) - drummer

(Source: Wikipedia)

[Website](http://www.yusukenakamura.net/) | [Twitter](https://x.com/kazekissa) | [Youtube](https://www.youtube.com/user/kazekissa) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/yusuke_nakamura_jp) | [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/yusukenakamura.jp/) | [Tiktok](https://www.tiktok.com/@kazekissa)

He is a designer, illustrator and musician. He graduated from Osaka University of Arts' Department of Arts majoring in Design.

Nakamura's artwork is frequently featured on album covers of bands such as Asian Kung-fu Generation and can be found on other sources such as in advertisements and in videogames such as Guitar Freaks.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/大野広司)

1977, he joined Kobayashi Production, where he studied under [Shichirou Kobayashi](https://anilist.co/staff/103964/). In 1982, he debuted as an art director on [Tonde Mon Pe](https://anilist.co/anime/6730/), and soon after that he left Kobayashi Production and took part in the founding of Studio Fuga with [Hiromasa Ogura](https://anilist.co/staff/105312/) and [Toshiharu Mizutani](https://anilist.co/staff/121908/). Later became, and is the current representative director of the studio.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E4%BC%8A%E6%9D%B1%E4%BC%B8%E9%AB%98)

Best known for his individual designs outside of the industry's norm.

Originating from Studio Dove. Itou started as an in-betweener on [Zettai Muteki Raijin Ou](https://anilist.co/anime/1897/) and made his debut as a character designer on the series [Kemonozume](https://anilist.co/anime/1454/), directed by [Masaaki Yuasa](https://anilist.co/staff/100068/). He has since designed the characters for most of Yuasa's works.
[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/lucillebriand)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/GongoraAbel) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/aberukuma/)

Abel Góngora is a Spanish animator and director known for his work with the Japanese animation studio Science SARU. Having joined the studio as one of its first employees, Góngora serves as the head of Science SARU's digital animation department and has specialized in the use of Adobe Animate.

Góngora began his career in Europe, joining the Irish animation studio Cartoon Saloon in 2006. He initially served as a location designer and later became an animator, working on the television series *"Skunk Fu!"* (2007–08). 

In 2007, Góngora moved to the French animation studio Ankama, where he worked as an animator on the initial seasons of the company's Flash-animated series *"Wakfu"* (2008–12). During this time, Ankama opened a Japanese subsidiary, Ankama Japan, and Góngora was one of the animators who temporarily relocated to Tokyo, where he collaborated with director Masaaki Yuasa. 

After Ankama Japan closed in 2011, Góngora returned to the main Ankama studio in France. However, he remained in touch with Yuasa and his producer associate Eunyoung Choi, and following the foundation of Science SARU in 2013, joined the new company.
[Website](https://batisteperron.com/)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/gotch_akg) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/gotch_akg/)

Lead vocalist of [Asian Kung-Fu Generation](https://anilist.co/staff/100251/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/gotch_akg) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/gotch_akg/)

Lead vocalist of [Asian Kung-Fu Generation](https://anilist.co/staff/100251/).

[Website](http://www.michiru-oshima.net/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/OshimaMichiru) | [Spotify](https://open.spotify.com/artist/6zqZlqpjrq3op255dF32Fr?autoplay=true)

She is a composer who has worked on several video game, movie, and television titles. Her works include composition for the video games Ico for PlayStation 2, Arc the Lad III, and an orchestral arrangement of a Zelda medley for the Wii and Gamecube game The Legend of Zelda: Twilight Princess. In addition to video game music, she has composed music for the Godzilla movies and scores for numerous anime television series, including Fullmetal Alchemist (and the motion picure Fullmetal Alchemist the Movie: Conqueror of Shamballa), Queen Emeraldas and Bounen no Xamdou. She was also the composer for a Japanese stage musical adaptation of the classic Hollywood film Roman Holiday.

Ooshima graduated from the Kunitachi College of Music, Department of Music Composition. Afterwards she began her activities as a composer and arranger while in college, and has been involved in making music for movies, commercials, TV programs, animated features, and ambient music. While in college, she released a symphony entitled "Orasho". Through her masterful manipulation of both orchestras and synthesizers, she has attracted attention from various sectors for creating grandiose, dramatic sounds and beautiful melodies. Her awards include the Mainichi Film Contest Award for Best Music, and the 21st, 24th, 26th, 27th, 29th and 30th Japanese Academy Award for Music, and Jackson Hole Film Festival 2007(USA) Best Composer Award.
Highly praised by [Masayuki Miyaji](https://anilist.co/staff/102156/) during the production of [Bounen no Xamdou](https://anilist.co/anime/4177/).
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/木村絵理子)
Freelancer formerly affiliated with [Telecom Animation Film](https://anilist.co/studio/94/).
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/清水賢治)
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/uedamakoto_ek)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/masaakiyuasa)

An acclaimed anime director known for his wild, freeform style. 

After graduating from the Kyushu Sangyo University's Faculty of Arts in 1987 he joined studio [Ajia-do](https://anilist.co/studio/30/Ajiado), initially as in-betweener but rapidly moving to key animation. 

In the first part of his career Yuasa established himself as an idiosyncratic creator while working on several child friendly anime, such as [Chibi Maruko-chan](https://anilist.co/anime/951/Chibi-Marukochan/) and [Doraemon](https://anilist.co/anime/2677/Doraemon-Nobitas-Animal-Planet/), but especially on [Crayon Shin-chan](https://anilist.co/anime/966/Shin-Chan/), a project he was involved with for most of the '90s. 

One of his breakthrough roles in this period was his participation on the second part of [The Hakkenden](https://anilist.co/anime/12715/The-Hakkenden-Legend-of-the-Dog-Warriors-Part-2/), working as animation director under [Shinya Oohira](https://anilist.co/staff/103893/Shinya-Oohira)'s direction. This OVA was an important outing of the '90s, uniting many veteran artists and talented newcomers. 

He debuted as director on [Mind Game](https://anilist.co/anime/875/Mind-Game/), an abstract piece combining animation and live-action footage, winning the 2004 Japan Media Arts Festival (overcoming even Hayao Miyazaki's [Howl's Moving Castle](https://anilist.co/anime/431/Howls-Moving-Castle/)), and earning [Yoshiyuki Tomino](https://anilist.co/staff/97337/Yoshiyuki-Tomino)'s praise, who acted as the chief judge. After Mind Game Yuasa spent several years at [MADHOUSE](https://anilist.co/studio/11/MADHOUSE) working on various projects. In 2013, he founded [Science SARU](https://anilist.co/studio/6145/Science-SARU) alongside his close affiliate [Eun-Yeong Choi](https://anilist.co/staff/115088/EunYeong-Choi).

On March 25, 2020 it was announced Yuasa stepped down as the CEO of Science SARU. He would work there as director until the completion of his latest Movie, [Inu-Oh](https://anilist.co/anime/109928/InuOh/), and would later cease any affiliation with the studio.

On February 17, 2025 it was announced that Yuasa would launch of his own animation studio, ame pippin. Their debut project would be the film [Daisy's Life](https://anilist.co/anime/190574/Hinagiku-no-Jinsei/).
